Document safe tg CLI operations for phase-golem items
description: Phase-golem recently migrated storage to task-golem (WRK-076), meaning the .task-golem/ store is now the shared persistence layer. The tg CLI can operate on this store directly, but phase-golem decorates items with x-pg-* extension fields that the tg CLI is unaware of.

x-pg-description.context: Phase-golem recently migrated storage to task-golem (WRK-076), meaning the .task-golem/ store is now the shared persistence layer. The tg CLI can operate on this store directly, but phase-golem decorates items with x-pg-* extension fields that the tg CLI is unaware of.
x-pg-description.impact: Provides operator guidance to prevent accidental state corruption when using the tg CLI directly, reducing debugging time and data integrity issues.
x-pg-description.problem: No documentation exists classifying which tg CLI operations are safe to run against a phase-golem-managed store vs. which ones risk corrupting phase-golem metadata or bypassing phase management logic.
x-pg-description.sizing_rationale: Single documentation file with no code changes. Requires understanding the extension field contract (already documented in pg_item.rs) and the tg CLI command set, but no architecture or design decisions.
x-pg-description.solution: Create a documentation file (e.g., docs/tg-cli-safety.md or a README section) that categorizes tg CLI commands into safe (read-only: list, show, ready, next, dump, doctor, completions), caution (status transitions: do, done, todo, block, unblock — bypass phase management), and dangerous (mutations: add, edit, rm — can create items without required extensions or destroy phase-golem metadata).

title: Migrate scheduler/executor error returns from String to PgError
description: PgError was introduced as a structured error type with retryable/fatal/skip categorization. The coordinator has been fully migrated, but scheduler (10 functions) and executor (2 functions) still return Result<_, String>, relying on a transitional From<PgError> for String bridge.

x-pg-description.context: PgError was introduced as a structured error type with retryable/fatal/skip categorization. The coordinator has been fully migrated, but scheduler (10 functions) and executor (2 functions) still return Result<_, String>, relying on a transitional From<PgError> for String bridge.
x-pg-description.impact: Enables proper error-based retry/halt logic throughout the pipeline. Unblocks tg-17988 (bridge removal). Completes the PgError migration across all core modules.
x-pg-description.problem: Structured error information is lost at the scheduler/executor boundary. Callers cannot distinguish retryable errors from fatal ones, and the transitional bridge prevents the error system from being fully leveraged.
x-pg-description.sizing_rationale: 2 core files (scheduler.rs ~75KB, executor.rs ~570 lines) plus test files and main.rs. 12 functions to update with repetitive but non-trivial changes — each string error site needs mapping to the correct PgError variant. Medium complexity due to variant selection decisions.
x-pg-description.solution: Update all 12 function signatures from Result<_, String> to Result<_, PgError>, convert string error creation sites to appropriate PgError variants, and update callers/tests. The existing PgError variants should cover all current error cases.
